is The One a myth? The One being the project that is so interesting that i _want_ to work on it for reasons other than the promise of a paycheck at the end. * 

* it is maybe important to note that i am typically paid for the sort of projects i do (computer software) even though i also do it as a hobby

honestly I go to work and just stare at social media or chase the office dog around the place and generally feel like i can't focus or do anything except for like the two days a month that it becomes clear i will be fired if i don't do at least something. 

it is somehow more exhausting than i remember working every day being

the _wanting_ part of your mind will never be satisfied. it's all good but you'll always want more. so if you fuel the machine by only 100% _want_, you'll always be more desperate and never satisfy those cravings. the good news is, what is also fun is a little exercise. if you've ever had a fun day in gym class (even just once, maybe when you were playing dodge ball, or maybe even just doing a line dance on that one day) then you'll know what i'm talking about. once you get everything together and take responsibility for this whole thing as a company, knowing that it's your company and it's allowed to do exactly what you want it to do, you may be able to hit that sweet spot and have a fun good time at work, while actually bit by bit bringing yourself the result of your dreams, in carryable packet sized buckets. even though you would have _wanted_ more, it turns out that as with most treats and sweets, it is given its sweetness by its limited daily quantities

I've been thinking a lot about how I'm going to die eventually. At first I was kinda sad, but I warmed up to the idea! After all, I haven't been alive for the billions of years preceding my birth. And being not alive wasn't that bad.

The thing is, I'm going to be really disappointed when I do have to die. I don't want to say goodbye to all my life experiences - the things I've done, the things I want to do, the people I love. I'll never know the things people will discover in the far-off future.

Thinking about giving that all up makes me want to cry, honestly. I don't want to die. I really REALLY don't want to die!!!!

i have seen two points.one point arguing that destroying every particle in your body and then reforming it would kill the 'you' you but give birth to a new someone who is entirely you and to their knowledge everything continued as normal, but the 'you' you is really gone.The other argument is that this new exact rearrangement of particles is you and would be the 'you' you and everything is fine.I have a hard time with each one but i think i lean towards the idea that the 'you' you won't be there anymore more when it is reformed.

i think this automatically happens to all of us. there is a persistent rumor that says our entire bodies entirely regenerate themselves over the course of several years, implying that you are now a completely different physical body than the one you are born with

i think this idea for some reason blends in with my thoughts about reincarnation.i also think there are extra problems to the situation like, what if when your particles are reformed they form 2 or 3 copies?
that would be a mindfuck but we would probably all learn something

then, if 'you' you are still around, which one is you?are both you?would it be like a clonal colony hive mind kind of thing?that doesn't make sense to me and damages the argument that 'you' you would be around.if everything is happening, perhaps what we are experiencing in this life happens infinite times.if it does, do 'i' really get to experience that many times?
eventually

i've been on a devastatingly long break from creating music (6 months at least), and it's absolutely killing me. i just lost it at the height of my career because of an insane amount of pressure (self-inflicted, mostly) to sound good and be an amazing pianist. also, i've been traveling this week and i'm staying in a house with a few other musicians. tonight i heard someone basically hitting the keys and playing with some cute chords, no recording or end goal or anything, just spending time with the instrument. and it filled me with relief and determination. because i guess ive been waaay too much of a perfectionist- and i've been too afraid to make mistakes while playing, to the point of deleting my confidence to even play. but, if this person can just hit some keys at 2 am and still manage to get some enjoyment and meaning from it, fuck what the hell am i holding back for? i forgot why i even fell in love with music: what the fuck is music and how can i make it myself

just put the same amount of energy into the music that you put into writing this. but on the other hand don't forget about writing too, because it seems clear that you already have a lot of energy for that too

Can you help explain drum notation to me?

the rhythms work the same, but instead of pitches, each line or space probably represents a different drum/cymbal/percussion item. usually the kick drum goes on the bottom, the cymbals usually go on top, usually with X heads, and the snare usually goes in the upper middle space. sometimes you see special markings above hi hat notes such as "O" or "+" which means open or closed. Which drum/item is which is usually labelled on the left before the start

how many key changes are there in mount st. helens?

let's see, it starts in G, there is a small hint or borrow from another key on "grey" but i really don't think that's long enough to call it a key change. then it doesn't change keys until the first bridge, which starts in Eb for the first half, then from "vacation" it would be in F (this is 2 key changes so far) then "paying them etc" would be in Ab, then back to G for the next verse. this makes 4 key changes so far. during this 3rd verse, it does a similar key slip that happens in the first verse (different key but similar place), but it lasts slightly longer than the one in the first verse, just long enough to declare it a key change maybe depending on who is judging that day. then back to G. so that makes 6 so far. then the second bridge, again to Eb in the first half (7 changes so far total). then on "sun burns out" there could be disagreement on which of those is considered a key change. i feel on 'sun' it seems like we are in Amin for just the moment, then the following chord actually feels like it's coming from the key of Cmin, which i would consider the same key as Eb. so i'd think that would be rude to say it changes to Amin and back for just that 1 chord, but then again on "sun" there is a distinct change. on the other hand, you could argue that they are both coming from the key of C, nah fuck it i guess you have to call that 2 keys. fine so we'll call that 2 key changes for "sun burns out." (that's 9 so far) but you see where this creates chaos in the courts because we've just allowed a single chord to be called its own key, twice in a row. so then it's only fair that we allow it back at the beginning also, for "grey." so that makes 2 extra changes because you'd have to count the change back also. so let me re count, that would be 11 so far, then from "sky" all the way to "goin down", that's all in Bb, so that's 1 more change. so 12 changes so far. then the top of the next verse stays in Bb but quickly slips to G, then the rest of the outvamp is in G which makes 13 changes if you include all the single chord incidents, and maybe 10 if you are more stubborn about including those

is it possible to have a tempo where the top number is bigger than the bottom number
tempos should be only 1 number, but you may be thinking of time signature
(like 4/3)?
you'll never see 3 on the bottom
If so how can it be executed?

the top number is the number of beats in a bar. the bottom number is what kind of note gets the beat. so 5/4 means there's 5 beats in a bar, and a quarter note gets one beat. 3/2 means there's 3 beats in a bar, and a half note gets one beat. if the bottom number is a 3 then i guess you'll have to figure out what 3rd notes are, which i guess you could conclude are triplets, in which case congratulations you now have something that looks exactly like 3/4 except for added fun you have to write the number 3 over every note in the song

It occurs to me that the confusion over the idea of an 'album' is down to a lack of agreement with regards to definition. I think you take the term 'album' quite literally, almost as the term photo album, i.e. a repository for a set of only loosely connected items. Most of the people arguing in favour of a Bill Wurtz album see the album in general as a sophisticated artwork that, in its most successful cases, has not a single note or word out of place and was conceived as a thematic whole, like a novel or a movie, and not as a random selection of songs. All the great albums are apparently random selections of songs, that reveal their inner logic and consistency only gradually, sometimes after many years. Pet Sounds and Rubber Soul fall into this category. You yourself have already made one total masterpiece of an album. Its most satisfying tracklisting (for me) runs as follows:

1) Alphabet Shuffle
2) Outside
3) And The Day Goes O n
4 ) at The Airport Terminal
5) Slow Down
6) Hallelujah
7) Hello Sexy Pants
8) Mount St Helens
9) La De Da De Da De Da De Day Oh
10) Long Long Journey
11) I'm Best Friends With My Own Front Door
12) When I Get Older
13) The Moon Is Made Of Cheese

The new album is also shaping up well ( Might Quit, Just Did A Bad Thing). I'm also not overlooking Christmas Isn't Real: it is my personal favourite of all your songs, but perhaps too high-concept to integrate easily into an album.

You have lifted the single song and video package onto the level of art form almost single-handedly. Pity us older music lovers who are still attached to our 45 minute programs, preferably broken into two halves. The album was our guiding principle, our mainstay, our educator and friend. No movie or novel (or music video) could ever approximate its awesome depth and breadth of vision. Only the truly great managed to master it as an art form, most crashed inexorably on its treacherous cliffs. Indeed, if you set out to create an album as a work of art you may already have shipwrecked. Its easily the most confounding mainstream modern artistic discipline. It's a shame it is really dying. Perhaps it is already dead?

What does a #### or bbbb in front of a staff/bass clef mean on sheet music??

if it says #### (and it HAS to be on the F, C, G, and D lines) it means play every F, C, G, and D note as F#, C#, G# and D# instead, which for the folks at home means we will be playing in the key of E. If it says ♭♭♭♭ (and it HAS to be on the B, E, A, and D lines) it means play every B, E, A, and D note as B♭, E♭, A♭, and D♭ instead, which for the folks at home means we will be playing in the key of A♭. how many key changes are there in "the moon is made of cheese but i can't taste it"?

let's see, starts in B, then for "crazy" i'd call that a switch to Ab, then back to B (that's 2 changes so far). Remind me etc. would be from key of Db, then from World was younger is from A, so that's 2 more changes there. TV on radio is definitely from Db, then around Stereo/leaves, we're in Bb, then landing on Turquoise we're back in B, so that's 3 more changes. 'Fly around on an airplane' sounds like it would be part of a song in E, then 'business class sec' would be in G, so that's 2 more changes. ants crawl is still G, then the next chord i could make a case for either E, A, or D, but regardless it's definitely a change. then B (turtles.) then on "streets" i would argue Db. and just linearly up from there (Eb, then F, then G.). so that's 6 more changes. then somewhere in the midst of 'church holds the key' it slips into C, so that's 1 more change. Then it goes to garbage land on the last line in the chords, but, the melody is still in C so i don't call that a change. so that's 16 changes if i counted correctly, according to what i think counts as a key change. using for sure 9 different keys, at least

(ref: q.php?date=201904301027)4.30.1910:27 am  It's like how you have several parts of your brain (limbic system, frontal lobe, occipital lobe, etc.) and even if some of them act independently of the others, "you" are still "aware of" what they do (create emotion, make judgements, process vision, respectively). And, in the case of, say, the occipital lobe, even if the neurons never receive signals from each other directly, the lobe is still "aware" of what the neurons do (aware meaning affecting behavior. In this case, what the neurons do determines how the lobe behaves, i.e. what it communicates to the other parts of the brain, and so we say the lobe is "aware of" the neurons' actions. Same applies for part of your brain affecting "you").
The ABC scenario is a just simple example of this Russian-nesting-doll of consciousness, where higher levels are aware of the thoughts of lower levels, but not vice-versa. My theory is that, just as a human has independent parts yet feels like a single experiencing mind and not like millions of tiny neuron minds, so too may there be a higher level of consciousness that feels like me and only me, you and only you, Benedict Cumberbatch and only Cumberbatch,  , and perhaps some non-person thoughts exclusive to the higher-level-consciousness.
That's what I mean by everyone is everyone else. By the theory, we are all just one entity that experiences many localized, I-am-me-and-noone-else perspectives. Of course I feel like me, and you feel like you. But that feeling of individual identity does not mean that our experiences are not just the thoughts of one single entity.

one of my biggest problems when combining melody with chords is that ending a melodic phrase by going M3 -> 1 is one of the strongest sounding melodic resolutions, but the strongest harmonic resolutions I know (V7->I, bII7->I, iv6->I) all do not work well with the M3rd of the tonic chord included (at least when the blending is clear enough to hear the dissonance). I know V13 is a thing, but I always think that sounds weird unless the 7th is lower than the 13th, which usually makes the chord sound muddy.
